abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Karachi Special
            Development Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory. The
            project achieved some of its overall objectives, its impact
            on institutional development has been significant,
            sustainability is unlikely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was marginally satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, project
            design should be simplified, focused on specific
            sub-sectors, and have more modest objectives. Second, while
            designing institutional strengthening and revenue generation
            proposals, political compulsion and administrative
            capabilities should be carefully analyzed. Third,
            inter-agency coordination must be improved and
            responsibilities consolidated at the metropolitan level for
            the efficient delivery of urban services. Fourth, greater
            community participation and ownership is required for
            upgrading low income communities. Fifth, greater borrower
            ownership and a longer term commitment of resources for
            technical assistance/training is required for making
            sustainable institutional improvements. Finally, private
            sector participation in the financing and operation of urban
            services may have a greater impact on the provision of
            services in the future than the traditional approach that
            has relied on the institutional and financial strengthening
            of public sector agencies.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Karachi Special
            Development Project are to: (a) strengthen the institutional
            and financial capacity of local agencies to deliver urban
            services; (b) improve resource mobilization and cost
            recovery; (c) demonstrate the feasibility of new approaches
            to providing services to the urban poor; and (d) directly
            improve basic urban services. These objectives will be
            achieved through a series of subsectoral interventions, with
            physical improvements combined with specific institutional
            and financial measures in the area of water and sewerage,
            flood control and drainage, transportation, katchi abadi
            upgrading, solid waste management, resource generation, and
            metropolitan management. The main risk to the project will
            be the ability of some of the implementing agencies to
            attract and retain capable staff.
